results.title: Hollywood on Trial
results.creator_credit: Cinema Associates, James Gutman and David Helpern Jr
results.brief_description: In 1947, the House of Un-American Activities Committee came to Los Angeles to investigate communism in the motion picture industry. This feature-length documentary details the hysteria and paranoia of the blacklist years which deeply divided America and Hollywood. This was a time of the Red Scare, loyalty checks and Joseph McCarthy, of the Hollywood Ten and the Motion Picture Alliance for the preservation of American Ideals, of film union wars and anti-communist movies - a time that America and Hollywood would like to forget.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cinema Associates, James Gutman and David Helpern Jr

results.title: Hollywood on parade
results.creator_credit: Intervision, Bud Friedgen and Bill Gleason
results.brief_description: Hollywood larger than life; Hollywood the dream factory; Hollywood the forgotten. From the fabulous to the flops to the freakish, this documentary narrated by Mickey Rooney focuses on Hollywood of the 1930s. It includes footage from the likes of Buster Keaton, Clark Gable, John Wayne, to the lesser-known faces of the chorus line and the many forgotten wannabes of the studio system. Focusing primarily on song and dance, this documentary has some wonderful sequences by Busby Berkeley, the always-impressive Mae West, and John Wayne as a singing quick-draw. As Mickey Rooney says, this is the Hollywood that “once was and is no more hurray for Hollywood”.

results.title: Hollywood ghost stories
results.creator_credit: Castle Hill Productions, Caidin Film Company, Julian Schlossberg and James M. Forsher
results.brief_description: Ghosts, haunted houses, poltergeists, exorcisms, the supernatural, this documentary explores it all. But what is more interesting is the focus on Hollywood and the films which have been produced, based either on pure fantasy or “real-life” experiences. Hosted by John Carradine, Hollywood ghost stories presents film excerpts, interviews and eye witness accounts from Hollywood producers, actors, set hands to authors, psychologists, and sceptics. William Peter Blatty, author of “The Exorcist” (1973) discusses strange occurrences which took place during production; Elke Sommer talks about her experiences living in a haunted house; Thelma Moss, Psychologist, compares the film “Poltergeist” (1982) with real-life poltergeists; Frank DeFellita, author and producer of “The Entity” (1981) comments on haunted houses and how “The Entity” was based on a true experience. Also features appearances by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and Susan Strasberg and includes excerpts from many of the earlier Hollywood films such as “Mystic circle murder” (1939), “I Married a witch” (1942) and “It’s a wonderful life” (1946).

results.title: Hollywood Costume: What is Costume Design? with Prof. D. Nadoolman Landis
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Kim Montgomery and Richard Greenhalgh
results.brief_description:
In a special event held at ACMI as part of the ‘Hollywood Costume’ exhibition, curator Professor Deborah Nadoolman Landis introduced the art of costume design and discussed its role in cinematic storytelling.
Landis, an Oscar®-nominated Hollywood costume designer (‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’, ‘The Blues Brothers’, Michael Jackson’s ‘Thriller’) is also the author of ‘Hollywood Costume’ (2012), the prize-winning exhibition catalogue, and ‘Hollywood Sketchbook: A Century of Costume Illustration’ (2012) among many other volumes.
Landis received her Ph.D. from the Royal College of Art in London and is the Founding Director of the David C. Copley Center for Costume Design at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television.

results.title: Hollywood Costume: Interview with Jan Chapman and Janet Patterson
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Kim Montgomery and Csilla Csongvay
results.brief_description:
The 2009 film ‘Bright Star’ (directed by Jane Campion)tells the story of the romance between the English poet John Keats (1795 - 1821)and Fanny Brawne.
In this interview, ‘Bright Star’ producer Jan Chapman and costume designer Janet Patterson discuss the creative process behind costume design, and the design choices that went into making one of the costumes for the character Fanny Brawne (played in the film by Abbie Cornish).
The character’s crimson gown costume was on display during the ACMI Melbourne Winter Masterpieces ‘Hollywood Costume’ exhibition (2013).
Clips from ‘Bright Star’ (2009) courtesy of Hopscotch Films.

results.title: Hollywood Costume: Deborah Nadoolman Landis interview
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Kim Montgomery and Csilla Csongvay
results.brief_description:
Professor Deborah Nadoolman Landis, an Oscar nominated Hollywood costume designer (‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’, ‘Blues Brothers’, Michael Jackson’s ‘Thriller’) is the author of ‘Hollywood Costume’ (2012), the prize-winning catalogue for the exhibition, and ‘Hollywood Sketchbook: A Century of Costume Illustration’ (2012) among many other volumes. Landis received her Ph.D. from the Royal College of Art in London and is the Founding Director of the David C. Copley Center for Costume Design at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television.
In this interview she talks about the origins of the Hollywood Costume industry, working as a costume designer, what a costume designer does and the relationship between the director and the costume designer.

results.title: Hollywood Costume. Inside the wardrobe: panel discussion
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Kim Montgomery and Richard Greenhalgh
results.brief_description:
This panel discussion explores the collaborative process between film director and costume designer, the link between costume and character and how costumes connect audiences with on-screen worlds. It also focuses on the artistic role of costuming in the filmmaking process.

Hear from leaders in costuming, film and fashion, the influential Australian film and television costumers Edie Kurzer (‘South Solitary’, ‘Look Both Ways’, ‘Matching Jack’) Cappi Ireland (‘I Frankenstein’, ‘Animal Kingdom’, ‘The Slap’) and Anna Borghesi (‘Mao’s Last Dancer’, ‘Ned Kelly’ ,’Romper Stomper’) in a discussion chaired by NIDA’s Head of Costume, Fiona Reilly.

results.title: Hollywood 10, Melbourne 1 = Hollywood ten, Melbourne one
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission, Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, Daryl Dellora and Ian Hansbrough
results.brief_description: A factual work that attempts to breath life into the biography of Frank Hardy by exploring his life through his pseudonym character, Ross Franklyn. Australian writer/novelist, Communist and eventual recluse after the death of his wife, Frank Hardy was a champion of the working class dedicated to writing about class outlook and human suffering. This unique documentary shows Frank Hardy talking of himself in the third person providing detective like clues that serve to inform the character, “Ross Franklyn”. Capturing the mood of the time the documentary discusses such themes as; the Cold War; Communism; organised crime; and poverty in Melbourne. Cast includes: John F. Howard, Rhonda Wilson, Bruce Knappet, David Gray and Susie Fraser. Directed, written and edited by Daryl Dellora.

results.title: Hollywood's musical moods
results.brief_description: Arthur Kleiner, former director of music at the Museum of Modern Art, examines the art of film music. He demonstrates examples of music used to accompany such silent films as “The Black pirate” and “Sunrise”, and interviews composers for sound films such as David Raksin and Miklos Rozsa. Film clips include excerpts from “Spellbound”, “Laura” and “High noon”. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels
